CORIDON.</br>Say shepheards boy, what makes thee greet so sore?</br>Why leaves thy pipe his pleasure and delight?</br>Yoong are thy yeares, thy cheeks with Roses dight:</br>Then sing for joy (sweet swain) and sigh no more.

This milk-white Poppy and this climbing Pine</br>Both promise shade, then sit thee downe and sing,</br>And make these woods with pleasant notes to ring,</br>Till Phoebus daine all Westward to decline.
MONTANUS.</br>Ah (Coridon) unmeet is melody</br>To him whom proud contempt hath overborn,</br>Slain are my joyes by Phoebus bitter scorn,</br>Far hence my weale and nere my jeopardy.
Loves burning brand is couched in my brest,</br>Making a Phoenix of my faintfull hart:</br>And though his fury doo inforce my smart,</br>Ay blyth am I to honour his behest.
Preparde to woes since so my Phoebe wils,</br>My lookes dismaid since Phoebe will disdain,</br>I banish blisse and welcome home my pain,</br>So stream my tears as showers from Alpine hils
In errors maske I blindfold judgements eye,</br>I fetter reason in the snares of lust,</br>I seeme secure, yet know not how to trust,</br>I live by that, which makes me living dye.
Devoyd of rest, companion of distresse,</br>Plague to my selfe, consumed by my thought,</br>How may my voyce or pipe in tune be brought?</br>Since I am reft of solace and delight.

CORIDON.</br>Ah Lorrell lad, what makes thee Herry love?</br>A sugred harme, a poyson full of pleasure,</br>A painted shrine ful-fild with rotten treasure,</br>A heaven in shew, a hell to them that prove.
Againe, in seeming shadowed stil with want,</br>A broken staffe which follie doth upholde,</br>A flower that fades with everie frostie colde,</br>An orient Rose sprong from a withred plant.
A minutes joy to gaine a world of griefe,</br>A subtil net to snare the idle minde,</br>A seeing Scorpion, yet in seeming blinde,</br>A poore rejoyce, a plague without reliefe.
For thy Montanus follow mine arreede,</br>(Whom age hath taught the traines that fancy useth)</br>Leave foolish love, for beautie wit abuseth,</br>And drownes (by folly) vertues springing seede.

MONTANUS.</br>So blames the childe the flame, because it burnes,</br>And bird the snare, because it doth intrap,</br>And fooles true love, because of sorry hap,</br>And saylers cursse the ship that overturnes.
But would the childe forbeare to play with flame,</br>And birds beware to trust the flowlers gin,</br>And fooles foresee before they fall and sin,</br>And maisters guide their ships in better frame.

The childe would praise the fire, because it warmes,</br>And birds rejoyce, to see the fowler faile,</br>And fooles prevent, before their plagues prevaile,</br>And saylers blesse the barke that saves from harmes.
Ah Coridon, though many be thy yeares;</br>And crooked elde hath some experience left,</br>Yet is thy mind of judgement quite bereft,</br>In view of love, whose power in me appeares.
The ploughman litle wots to turn the pen,</br>Or bookeman skils to guide the ploughmans cart,</br>Nor can the cobler count the tearmes of Art,</br>Nor base men judge the thoughts of mighty men.
Nor withered age (unmeet for beauties guide,</br>Uncapable of loves impressien)</br>Discourse of that, whose choyce possession</br>May never to so base a man be tied.
But I (whom nature makes of tender mold,</br>And youth most pliant yeelds to fancies fire)</br>Do build my haven and heaven on sweet desire,</br>On sweet desire more deere to me than gold.
Thinke I of love, O how my lines aspire?</br>How hast the Muses to imbrace my browes,</br>And hem my temples in with lawrell bowes,</br>And fill my braines with chast and holy fire?
Then leave my lines their homely equipage,</br>Mounted beyond the circle of the Sunne:</br>Amazd I read the stile when I have done,</br>And Herry Love that sent that heavenly rage.
Of Phoebe then, of Phoebe then I sing,</br>Drawing the puritie of all the spheares,</br>The pride of earth, or what in heaven appeares,</br>Her honoured face and fame to light to bring.

In fluent numbers and in pleasant vaines,</br>I robbe both sea and eath of all their state,</br>To praise her parts:  I charme both time and fate</br>To blesse the Nymph that yeelds me love sicke paines.
My sheepe are turnd to thoughts, whom froward will</br>Guydes in the restles Laborynth of Love,</br>Feare lends them pasture where so ere they move,</br>And by their death their life renueth still.
My sheepehooke is my pen, mine oaten reed,</br>My paper, where my many woes are written:</br>Thus silly swaine (with love and fancie bitten)</br>I trace the plaines of paine in wofull weed.
Yet are my cares, my broken sleepes, my teares,</br>My dreames, my doubts, for Phoebe sweet to me:</br>Who wayteth heaven in sorrowes vale must be,</br>And glory shines where daunger most appeares.
Then Coridon although I blith me not,</br>Blame me not man since sorrow is my sweet:</br>So willeth Love, and Phoebe thinkes it meet,</br>And kind Montanus liketh well his lot.

CORIDON.</br>Oh staylesse youth, by errour so misguided,</br>Where will prescribeth lawes to perfect wits,</br>Where reason mournes, and blame in triumph sits,</br>And folly poysoneth all that time provided.
With wilfull blindnesse bleard, prepard to shame,</br>Prone to neglect Occasion when she smiles:</br>Alas that Love by fond and froward guiles,</br>Should make thee tract the path to endlesse blame.
Ah (my Montanus) cursed is the charme,</br>That hath bewitched so thy youthfull eyes?</br>Leave off in time to like these vanities,</br>Be forward to thy good, and fly thy harme.
As many bees as Hibla daily shields,</br>As many frie as fleet on Oceans face,</br>As many heards as on the earth do trace,</br>As many flowers as decke the fragrant fields.
As many stars as glorious heaven contains,</br>As many storms as wayward winter weepes,</br>As many plagues as hell inclosed keepes:</br>So many griefs in love, so many pains.

Suspitions, thoughts, desires, opinions, prayers;</br>Mislikes, misdeeds, fondioies, and fained peace,</br>Illusions, dreames, great paines, and small increase,</br>Vowes, hope, acceptance, scorns, and deepe despaires.

Truce, warre, and wo do wait at beauties gate:</br>Time lost, laments, reports, and privy grudge,</br>And last, fierce Love is but a partiall Judge,</br>Who yeelds for service shame, for friendship hate.

MONTANUS.</br>All adder-like I stop mine eares (fond swaine)</br>So charme no more, for I will never change.</br>Call home thy flocks betime that stragling range:</br>For loe, the Sunne declineth hence amaine.
Terentius.  In amore haec insunt vitia:  induciae, inimicitia, bellum, pax rursum:  incerta haec situ postules, ratione cert a fieri nihilo plus agas, quam fides operam, ut cum ratione insanias.</br>
